did.unittitle: American and Foreign Christian Union records

bioghist.p: The American and Foreign Christian Union was formed in 1849. The Union was comprised of three complementary missionary societies: the American Protestant Society, the Foreign Evangelical Society and the Christian Alliance. By 1860 the AFCU supported 73 workers in the U.S. and granted subsidies to help support 212 foreign workers. Most AFCU officers were leading members of the clergy who were also active in other interdenominational benevolent societies. By 1884 the AFCU focused solely on the American Church in Paris, which it had founded earlier. The American Church in Berlin traces it roots to about 1865 when an American Chapel was founded. Changing its name to the American Church in Berlin in 1886, it made first contact with the AFCU in 1889. In 1914 the AFCU took on the responsibility for managing a fund to support the American Church in Berlin. The stated mission of the American and Foreign Christian Union is "to support the International, English speaking, ecumenical churches whose ministries bear witness to Jesus Christ. In partnership with our member churches, we will strive to develop and manage a strong financial base to further their programs. We will nurture and strengthen our alumni ties and lend support to the pastors, leadership and members of these churches through our care and prayers."

scopecontent.p: Included are minutes of AFCU annual meetings and executive and finance committee meetings, 1974-2006, with some gaps; financial records, 1997-1998; a 1999 report on the American Church in Berlin; budgets; reports; list of Board members; and the constitution, 1983-1996. The collection includes a photocopy of the deed for the 65 Quai d'Orsay property in Paris, dated 1925. Also included are research materials used to write a history of the American Church in Paris, including historical information about AFCU and the American Church in Paris; lists of Pastors of the American church; notes on newspaper articles about the AFCU; lists of materials in the archives of the American Church in Paris; photocopies and photostats of records and articles on the American Church in Paris and its clergy; as well as several bulletins and brochures from the American Church in Paris, 1940s. Additionally, the collection includes a constitution and by-laws; tax exemption forms; records of files at the Presbyterian Historical Society; historical background documents; copies of articles and printed materials on the American Church in Berlin and some about the American Church in Paris; AFCU minutes, 1966-1974; AFCU correspondence, 1974-1983; flyers; newsletters; programs for American Church in Paris events; reports; correspondence related to the American Church in Berlin; a cookbook of the American Church in Berlin; and a calendars of events.
